questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a 2-month history of persistent diarrhea, a worsening rash on his hands and neck, and episodes of memory lapses and confusion. His diet primarily consists of untreated maize (corn). Which vitamin deficiency is he most likely suffering from? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pellagra, caused by niacin deficiency, presents with a triad of symptoms: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. A diet primarily consisting of untreated maize can increase the risk of this deficiency.

questions.text: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for diagnosis of which of the following condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Toxoplasmosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Sabin-Feldman dye test remains a gold standard for the serological diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis due to its ability to detect the presence of specific antibodies against Toxoplasma gondii, reflecting the body's immune response to the infection.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Skin test for diagnosis of parasitic infections:
  • ➤ Casoni test – Hydatid disease Montenegro test – Kala azar Frenkel test – Toxoplasmosis Fairley test – Schistosomiasis Bachman test – Trichinellosis
  • ➤ Casoni test – Hydatid disease
  • ➤ Casoni test
  • ➤ Montenegro test – Kala azar
  • ➤ Montenegro test
  • ➤ Frenkel test – Toxoplasmosis
  • ➤ Fairley test – Schistosomiasis
  • ➤ Bachman test – Trichinellosis

questions.text: During the assessment of the breathing component of a trauma patient, which of the following is the most life-threatening injury that should be identified and managed immediately? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Tension pneumothorax

questions.text: Which Reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Bainbridge reflex

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. J Reflex : Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.
  • • Option A. J Reflex
  • • Option B. Cushing Reflex : Incorrect because the Cushing reflex involves increased blood pressure, bradycardia, and respiratory depression in response to increased intracranial pressure, not right atrial distension.
  • • Option B. Cushing Reflex
  • • Option C. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex : Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.
  • • Option C.
  • • Bezold-Jarisch Reflex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for inducing tachycardia in response to right atrial distension. It serves to adjust heart rate upward when venous return to the heart increases, ensuring optimal cardiac output and circulation efficiency.

questions.text: A child developed multiple skin eruptions/burns after exposure to sunlight. Which of the following is the likely defect present in her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.correct_answer: B. Nucleotide excision repair gene defect
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Xeroderma pigmentosum is caused by a defect in the nucleotide excision repair gene, leading to severe sensitivity to UV light, skin eruptions, and an increased risk of skin cancers

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing mortality trends among children aged between 1-4 years based on verbal autopsy reports from the years 2010-2013. She wants to educate parents on the primary causes of death to improve preventive measures in her community. From the list provided below, which sequence correctly represents the leading causes of death in a descending order for this age group? (INICET MAY 2021) Diarrhea Pneumonia Malaria Injuries
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2>1>4>3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a developed country, leading causes of death are:
  • ➤ Accident injury Congenital anomaly Neoplasms Influenza Pneumonia
  • ➤ Accident injury
  • ➤ Congenital anomaly
  • ➤ Neoplasms

questions.text: Heavy metal chelators are all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oxime

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heavy metal chelators play a crucial role in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. They work by binding to toxic heavy metals and aiding in their elimination from the body. Each heavy metal chelator may have specific indications and is used for particular heavy metal poisonings.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chronic SDH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A crescent or moon-shaped, hypodense (dark) collection on a CT scan suggests a chronic subdural hematoma (SDH).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used to prevent painful vaso-occlusive crises and decrease long-term complications in sickle cell anemia? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hydroxyurea.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydroxyurea is the primary medication used to prevent painful vaso-occlusive crises and decrease long-term complications in sickle cell anemia by increasing the concentration of fetal hemoglobin (HbF).

questions.text: While administering epidural anesthesia, which structure is not punctured before injecting the drug? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Arachnoid mater

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During epidural anesthesia, the anesthetic agent is injected into the epidural space, which lies outside the dura mater. The needle passes through several layers of tissue but does not puncture the dura mater, arachnoid mater, or enter the subarachnoid space.
  • • The layers that are punctured during epidural anesthesia, in order, are:
  • • Skin Superficial fascia Supraspinous ligament Interspinous ligament Ligamentum flavum
  • • Skin
  • • Superficial fascia
  • • Supraspinous ligament
  • • Interspinous ligament
  • • Ligamentum flavum
  • • After passing through the ligamentum flavum, the needle enters the epidural space, where the anesthetic agent is deposited.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Supraspinous ligament : This ligament is punctured during epidural anesthesia.
  • • Option A. Supraspinous ligament
  • • Option B. Interspinous ligament : This ligament is also punctured during the procedure.
  • • Option B. Interspinous ligament
  • • Option C. Ligamentum flavum : The needle passes through the ligamentum flavum to reach the epidural space.
  • • Option C. Ligamentum flavum :
  • • Note : that this procedure differs from a lumbar puncture, where the needle passes through the dura mater, arachnoid mater, and enters the subarachnoid space (represented by the mnemonic "DAS": Dura mater, Arachnoid mater, Subarachnoid space).
  • • Note

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During epidural anesthesia, the arachnoid mater is not punctured. The anesthetic agent is injected into the epidural space, which lies outside the dura mater, after passing through the skin, superficial fascia, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, and ligamentum flavum.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about triage? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Yellow: urgent care needed

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Yellow in triage signifies that urgent care is needed, such as for open fractures or degloving injuries.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the actions of endothelin-1 except? ( NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Bronchodilation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Contrary to bronchodilation, ET-1 actually causes bronchoconstriction in the lungs, mediated through ET-B receptors. This makes it detrimental in respiratory pathologies.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Vasoconstriction : Correct and a well-documented action of ET-1.
  • • Option B. Vasoconstriction
  • • Option C. Decreased GFR : Correct, as ET-1 affects renal blood flow and filtration.
  • • Option C. Decreased GFR
  • • Option D. Has inotropic effect : Correct, ET-1 increases the force of heart contractions.
  • • Option D. Has inotropic effect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)
  • ➤ Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)
  • ➤ On blood vessels - Potent vasoconstrictor, vascular growth, matrix production inflammation → can lead to atherosclerosis, Pulmonary artery hypertension, systemic hypertension On heart – Inotropic effect, Apoptosis, cardiomyocytes and cardio fibroblast growth and metabolism → can lead to heart failure, cardiac fibrosis, cardiac hypertrophy In the kidneys - involved in Tubuloglomerular feedback - \ GFR leads to diuresis, natriuresis, glomerular filtration, renal blood flow. Maybe be involved in glomerulosclerosis diabetic nephropathy, polycystic kidney disease, proteinuric diseases, hypertension. In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors) In the brain, - regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB). In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads to Hirschsprung's/megacolon). Platelet activation Closure of ductus arteriosus. Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 gene - craniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.
  • ➤ On blood vessels - Potent vasoconstrictor, vascular growth, matrix production inflammation → can lead to atherosclerosis, Pulmonary artery hypertension, systemic hypertension
  • ➤ On heart – Inotropic effect, Apoptosis, cardiomyocytes and cardio fibroblast growth and metabolism → can lead to heart failure, cardiac fibrosis, cardiac hypertrophy
  • ➤ In the kidneys - involved in Tubuloglomerular feedback - \ GFR leads to diuresis, natriuresis, glomerular filtration, renal blood flow. Maybe be involved in glomerulosclerosis diabetic nephropathy, polycystic kidney disease, proteinuric diseases, hypertension.
  • ➤ In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors)
  • ➤ In the brain, - regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB).
  • ➤ In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads to Hirschsprung's/megacolon).
  • ➤ Platelet activation
  • ➤ Closure of ductus arteriosus.
  • ➤ Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 gene - craniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.

  • ➤ Congenital heart disease (in about 35% of cases)
  • ➤ Gastrointestinal anomalies (in about 10%)
  • ➤ Chronic serous otitis media (in >50%)
  • ➤ Chronic serous otitis media (in >50%)
  • ➤ Hypothyroidism
  • ➤ Alzheimer's disease (in the 30's and 40's)
  • ➤ Alzheimer's disease (in the 30's and 40's)
  • ➤ Epilepsy (in about 10%)
  • ➤ Ocular disorders
  • ➤ Reduced fertility
  • ➤ Reduced life span (Often due to complications like infections)

questions.text: Mention the type of joint present at the marked area: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Saddle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows the hand, with the arrow pointing to the first carpometacarpal joint, which is the joint between the carpal bone (trapezium) and the first metacarpal bone (base of the thumb). This joint is a classical example of a saddle joint.
  • • In a saddle joint, one bone has a concave and convex surface that articulates with the complementary convex and concave surface of the other bone, resembling a saddle shape. The joint is surrounded by a capsule and filled with synovial fluid.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ellipsoid: An ellipsoid joint has an oval-shaped articular surface that fits into an elliptical cavity, allowing for biaxial movement. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.
  • • Option A. Ellipsoid:
  • • Option B. Condylar: A condylar joint has an oval projection of one bone fitting into an elliptical cavity of another bone, allowing for biaxial movement. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.
  • • Option B. Condylar:
  • • Option C. Plane: A plane joint has two flat or slightly curved articular surfaces that allow for gliding or sliding movements. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.
  • • Option C. Plane:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first carpometacarpal joint at the base of the thumb is a saddle joint, allowing a wide range of thumb movements.
  • ➤ Saddle Joint – Mnemonic – PICS
  • ➤ – PICS
  • ➤ Concavo-convex surface in each bone
  • ➤ P – Patellofemoral joint
  • ➤ P
  • ➤ I – incudomalleolar joint
  • ➤ I
  • ➤ C – Carpometacarpal joint
  • ➤ C
  • ➤ S – Sternoclavicular joint
  • ➤ S

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Early diagnosis and treatment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early diagnosis and treatment (secondary prevention) are the most effective methods for preventing the progression of breast cancer, as they allow for early detection and intervention, significantly improving the chances of successful treatment and reducing mortality rates.

questions.text: During a global health conference, you're in a discussion with fellow epidemiologists about the changing patterns of disease occurrence over the years. The conversation shifts towards the steady rise in non-communicable diseases over a considerable time span. One of your colleagues quizzes the group on the terminology for such a trend. Which term best describes this pattern of increasing prevalence over extended periods? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Secular

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Secular trends describe long-term changes in disease occurrence over years or decades, distinct from seasonal or cyclical variations.
  • ➤ Secular trends describe long-term changes in disease occurrence over years or decades, distinct from seasonal or cyclical variations.

questions.text: When considering a patient with lung cancer, the imaging studies have measured the tumor size at 2.5 cm. According to the TMN staging system, which stage would be appropriate for this patient? ( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) T1c

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The TNM staging system for lung cancer uses tumor size and extent (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M) to classify the disease. A tumor measuring 2.5 cm is classified as T1c according to the TNM 8th edition criteria.

questions.text: A patient presents with an BT leprosy lesion on the face as shown in the image below. Which of the following nerves is most commonly involved in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Facial Nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients presenting with leprosy lesions on the face, the most commonly involved nerve is the facial nerve (option A).

questions.text: During rounds, your senior was discussing the given image. The following is an image of which of the following investigations? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. CT scan

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The above given image is a CT scan image since the bone can be identified as a high-density structure which appears white.
  • • CT scan is an imaging modality which uses X-rays for cross sectional images of the body and the density of the tissue through which this x-ray beam passes is measured from the calculation of attenuation coefficient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Contrast Dye study: While contrast may be used in CT scans, the term "contrast dye study" alone does not specifically indicate a CT scan.
  • • Option A. Contrast Dye study:
  • • Option B. X-ray: Typically provides two-dimensional imaging and lacks the cross-sectional detail shown in these images.
  • • Option B. X-ray:
  • • Option C. D Angiography: Focuses on blood vessels using contrast material and typically does not provide detailed images of other anatomical structures as seen in these scans.
  • • Option C. D Angiography:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CT scans are invaluable in medical imaging for providing detailed cross-sectional views of internal structures, utilizing X-ray technology to distinguish between different tissue densities, evident from the white appearance of bone and detailed soft tissue visualization in the images.

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Collect water from already leaking taps

options.label: B
options.text: Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute

options.label: C
options.text: Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage

options.label: D
options.text: Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.correct_answer: D. Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When collecting water for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing and potential contamination. This practice ensures the accuracy and reliability of the water sample.

questions.text: Which structure develops from the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ductus arteriosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ductus arteriosus, a critical structure in fetal circulation, develops from the distal part of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver in image below. (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pringle's maneuver

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image depicts a surgical procedure known as Pringle's maneuver, which involves inserting a finger from the greater sac to the lesser sac through the epiploic foramen (also known as the foramen of Winslow). The epiploic foramen is the communication between the greater and lesser sacs, and its boundaries are of great importance.
  • • During hepatobiliary surgery, there is a risk of rupturing the vein, artery, and duct (VAD) located along the free margin of the lesser omentum. To prevent leakage from these structures, the surgeon can either clamp them along the free margin or insert a finger behind the lesser omentum and place the thumb above it, compressing the VAD between the finger and thumb. This surgical procedure is known as Pringle's maneuver.
  • • The maneuver involves inserting the finger in front of the stomach (greater sac) and passing it behind the stomach (lesser sac) through the epiploic foramen.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mattox maneuver: Incorrect. The Mattox maneuver is a surgical technique used to control bleeding from the inferior vena cava or hepatic veins during liver trauma. It involves a thoracoabdominal approach and manual compression of the bleeding site.
  • • Option A. Mattox maneuver:
  • • Option C. Cattell-Braash maneuver: Incorrect. The Cattell-Braash maneuver is a surgical technique used to expose the retroperitoneal structures, such as the aorta, inferior vena cava, and kidneys, by mobilizing the colon and small bowel to the right side of the abdomen.
  • • Option C. Cattell-Braash maneuver:
  • • Option D. Liver hanging maneuver: Incorrect. The liver hanging maneuver is a technique used during liver resection to facilitate the transection of the liver parenchyma. It involves passing a tape or a catheter between the liver and the inferior vena cava to provide traction and guidance during the resection.
  • • Option D. Liver hanging maneuver:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pringle's maneuver is a surgical procedure used to control bleeding during hepatobiliary surgery by compressing the vein, artery, and duct (VAD) along the free margin of the lesser omentum through the epiploic foramen.

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Minimal change disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Effacement of podocyte foot processes is the characteristic feature of minimal change disease (MCD), which presents with nephrotic syndrome and shows normal glomeruli on light microscopy but diffuse foot process flattening on electron microscopy.

questions.text: Most important enzyme in acute inflammation during respiratory burst is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) NADPH oxidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NADPH oxidase is the most important enzyme in the process of respiratory burst during acute inflammation. It initiates the production of reactive oxygen species, which are crucial for the immune system's ability to kill pathogens.

questions.text: What diseases' risk is elevated due to smoking? ( INICET MAY 2023) Duct ectasia Fibroadenoma Mondor's disease Breast carcinoma
questions.explanation: Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

questions.text: A chronic cigarette smoker now joined a construction company. His pulmonary function test results are given below.(INICET MAY 2023) Initial lung volumes were: FEV1 - 0.9L, FVC - 1.9L, FEV1/FVC - 0.4 After bronchodilation: FEV1 - 1.9L, FVC - 3.9L, FEV1/FVC - 0.4 What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Restrictive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility

options.label: C
options.text: Restrictive lung disease without bronchodilator reversibility

questions.correct_answer: D. Obstructive disease with bronchodilator reversibility
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Obstructive disease with bronchodilator reversibility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obstructive lung diseases, such as asthma or COPD, may show bronchodilator reversibility.

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, what is the amount of oxygen you will start with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 21%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, resuscitation should start with 21% oxygen, equivalent to room air, to minimize the risk of oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with organophosphate poisoning. He was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the likely cause of fever? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atropine toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The given image is the logo for which of the following health programs? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) National Leprosy Eradication Program

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The National Leprosy Eradication Program logo symbolizes hope, the curability of leprosy, and the inclusion of cured individuals into society, promoting a stigma-free approach towards the disease.

questions.text: What treatment should be avoided for a male patient in his mid-40s who was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident, and presents with a heart rate of 120/min, respiratory rate of 30/min, and an X-ray image of his chest? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chest tube insertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The provided image displays an elevated left hemidiaphragm with stomach herniated into thorax, likely due to a diaphragmatic hernia resulting from blunt trauma in a road traffic accident.
  • ➤ Chest tube insertion or thoracostomy is not recommended in cases of diaphragmatic hernia and is contraindicated Chest tube insertion is generally indicated for pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, pleural effusion, among others, but is contraindicated in the presence of pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia. To insert a chest tube, the 5th intercostal space should be accessed anterior to the midaxillary line, within the triangle of safety, which is located above the level of the nipple and below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle. Acquired diaphragmatic hernia does not contraindicate nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia.
  • ➤ Chest tube insertion or thoracostomy is not recommended in cases of diaphragmatic hernia and is contraindicated
  • ➤ Chest tube insertion is generally indicated for pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, pleural effusion, among others, but is contraindicated in the presence of pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia.
  • ➤ To insert a chest tube, the 5th intercostal space should be accessed anterior to the midaxillary line, within the triangle of safety, which is located above the level of the nipple and below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
  • ➤ Acquired diaphragmatic hernia does not contraindicate nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient with a midline neck swelling and histopathological findings of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on biopsy as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Papillary carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on histopathological examination is a key diagnostic feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.correct_answer: D. Weight for height less than - 3SD
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Weight for height less than -3SD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by the WHO as weight-for-height (or length) below -3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards, presence of bilateral pitting edema, or mid-upper arm circumference less than 11.5 cm.

questions.text: A pregnant woman was prescribed indomethacin. Which of the following effects does the drug have on the fetus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.correct_answer: A. Premature closure of ductus arteriosus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indomethacin, an NSAID, can cause the premature closure of the ductus arteriosus in a fetus due to its inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis. Therefore, caution should be exercised when prescribing this drug to pregnant women, particularly in the third trimester.

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic feature of hemolysis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decreased haptoglobin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decreased haptoglobin is a characteristic feature of hemolysis, distinguishing it from other conditions.

questions.text: A farmer is spraying an odourless chemical in the fields, which is an Inhibitor of Complex III of ETC. Identify the compound: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Antimycin A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhibitors of ETC:
  • ➤ Inhibitors of ETC:
  • ➤ Complex I- Rotenone, Phenobarbitone, Amobarbital
  • ➤ Complex II- Malonate (3C), Carboxin
  • ➤ Complex III- Phenformin, Antimycin A, BAL
  • ➤ Complex IV- CN, CO, Sodium azide, H2S
  • ➤ Pesticides used in agricultural fields:
  • ➤ Pesticides used in agricultural fields:
  • ➤ Rotenone is also an insecticide, pesticide and a herbicide Carboxin is a fungicide that is commonly used in agricultural practices Antimycin – used in agriculture to control certain pests that affect crops Cyanide
  • ➤ Rotenone is also an insecticide, pesticide and a herbicide
  • ➤ insecticide, pesticide and a herbicide
  • ➤ Carboxin is a fungicide that is commonly used in agricultural practices
  • ➤ Antimycin – used in agriculture to control certain pests that affect crops
  • ➤ Cyanide
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 127
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 127

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was operated for a tumour in the lower end of femur. The gross specimen of the resected tumour is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur. The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.
  • ➤ The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur.
  • ➤ The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.

questions.text: The observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match the ECG findings of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Takotsubo cardiomyopathy should be considered when a patient's clinical presentation includes myocardial stunning that does not correspond to ECG findings typical of a myocardial infarction, especially in the context of recent significant emotional or physical stress.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Cardiomyopathies/Chap 259

questions.text: Which among the following is the most specific disease caused by Streptococcus agalactiae?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neonatal sepsis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis.
